intro: Ligusticum capillaceum, commonly known as slender lovage, is a perennial herb native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia, particularly in countries like Afghanistan and Pakistan. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots, parsley, and celery, and is characterized by its aromatic, finely divided leaves. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with slender, branching stems and small, greenish-yellow flowers that appear in umbels. Its leaves are often used in traditional medicine for their purported digestive and anti-inflammatory properties. The plant thrives in rocky, well-drained soils and is often found in alpine meadows at high elevations.
